questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C: Onchocerca volvulus

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D: Chlamydia A to C

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text: A nurse removes her latex gloves contaminated with blood and bodily fluids after a procedure. According to biomedical waste management guidelines, into which colored bag should she place the used gloves for disposal? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Red

 

  • Latex gloves contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids are considered contaminated waste (recyclable) and should be disposed of in red-colored bags or containers.
  • This category includes items like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), and gloves.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presented with fatigue and pallor. Investigations show Hb = 5.8 gm/dl, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, high RDW. Diagnosis is? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron Deficiency Anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin levels, low ferritin (indicating depleted iron stores), high total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), and high red cell distribution width (RDW). These laboratory findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia:

 

  • Low ferritin indicates depleted iron stores.
  • High TIBC reflects an increase in the body's attempt to capture more iron due to deficiency.
  • Low MCV signifies microcytic anemia, common in iron deficiency.
  • High RDW indicates variability in red cell size, often seen in iron deficiency as the body produces new, smaller red cells alongside older, larger ones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Megaloblastic Anemia: Typically presents with high MCV (macrocytic anemia) due to deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate, not low MCV.

 

Option C. Anemia of Chronic Disease: Often presents with normal or high ferritin (reflecting inflammation or infection) and low TIBC, not high TIBC.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic Anemia: Generally associated with increased iron stores, not low ferritin, and may show a dimorphic blood picture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is indicated by low hemoglobin, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, and high RDW.

choices.text: Bath the baby with warm water immediately

questions.text: A mother delivers a 2.5 kg baby with normal vaginal delivery in a rural area. Which of the following is an incorrect statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bath the baby with warm water immediately

     

Newborn care practices emphasize immediate and appropriate actions to ensure the health and safety of the infant. Bathing the baby immediately after birth is discouraged because the baby's skin needs to adapt to the new environment, and the vernix (a protective layer on the skin) should be allowed to remain on the skin for as long as possible to provide a barrier against infection. Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is generally not recommended, especially in settings where environmental conditions (such as warmth and cleanliness) are not optimal.

 

The recommended practice is to wait at least 24 hours and then start with gentle sponging until the umbilical cord falls off, typically within the first week of life. Only after this can full baths be introduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exclusive breastfeeding: This is the recommended feeding method for newborns, providing optimal nutrition and immunity support. It should be started within the first hour of birth.

 

Option C. Clean the eyes: Cleaning the eyes is a standard neonatal practice to prevent infection. This is part of routine newborn care and helps prevent neonatal conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Skin to skin contact: Skin-to-skin contact is encouraged immediately after birth as it helps regulate the newborn's body temperature, promotes bonding, and supports breastfeeding initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended; it should be delayed until the umbilical cord falls off, and gentle sponging should be started after 24 hours to maintain hygiene and prevent hypothermia.

questions.text: A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis. Further investigations revealed cardiomegaly. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

The given clinical presentation with pedal edema and cardiomegaly is suggestive of wet beriberi, which is a consequence of thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, is a more likely candidate. Thiamine deficiency can manifest as cardiac beriberi, leading to an enlarged heart (cardiomegaly), which aligns with the clinical findings. Thiamine deficiency can also cause peripheral edema, such as pedal edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Riboflavin deficiency can lead to cheilosis, which is consistent with one of the symptoms observed. However, it is not typically associated with pedal edema or cardiomegaly.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency is not commonly associated with pedal edema, cheilosis, or cardiomegaly.

 

Option D. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes symptoms like dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is not typically associated with cardiomegaly or pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 deficiency disorders

questions.text: A patient with loin pain underwent retrograde ureter pyelogram to determine the cause of the pain. What is the likely cause of the pain as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydronephrosis

 

The presence of dilated clubbed calyces and a stricture at the left ureteropelvic junction in the given image is indicative of hydronephrosis, which is caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow in the pelvicalyceal system. This condition can arise when there's an obstruction preventing urine from draining out of the kidney and down the ureter. Over time, this causes the kidney to swell and its internal structures, like the calyces, to dilate. Retrograde ureteropyelogram can reveal the classic signs of hydronephrosis such as dilated and clubbed calyces, and any blockage, for instance, at the ureteropelvic junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duplex kidney: A duplex kidney is a congenital anomaly where the kidney has two collecting systems. This means there are two ureters draining a single kidney, although sometimes the two ureters can fuse before entering the bladder. A retrograde ureteropyelogram can identify a duplex system by visualizing the two separate collecting systems and ureters. However, this option isn't the described condition causing the pain based on the information provided.

 

Option C. Renal carcinoma: Patients with renal carcinoma are likely to present with gross hematuria, while pain is late feature. While a retrograde ureteropyelogram can show filling defects, irregularities, or obstructions in the renal collecting system which could be caused by a tumor, it isn't the primary tool used for diagnosing renal carcinoma. Imaging methods like CT scans or MRIs are more commonly used for visualizing renal masses.

 

Option D. Renal stone: Kidney stones (renal calculi) present with flank pain and hematuria. On a retrograde ureteropyelogram, a kidney stone might show up as a filling defect or blockage. The location, size, and shape of the stone can often be identified. However, based on the information provided, the image indicates hydronephrosis and not a stone.

 

Educational Objective:


Hydronephrosis is characterized by the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to an obstruction in urine flow, leading to swelling of the kidney and pain, typically visualized via imaging like a retrograde ureteropyelogram.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic. She has a regular 28-day cycle. How should she be evaluated? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum progesterone on day 21

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, serum progesterone is typically measured on day 21 to assess for ovulation. Progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle provide information about whether ovulation has occurred.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation.
  • Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.

 

Other tests for ovulation:

 

  • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation.
  • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge.
  • Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation.
  • Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14: Measuring progesterone on day 14 is not useful as it corresponds to the follicular phase when progesterone levels are low and not indicative of ovulation.

 

Option C. Serum LH on day 14: While an LH surge around day 14 can indicate impending ovulation, it does not confirm that ovulation has actually occurred.

 

Option D. Serum LH on day 21: Measuring LH on day 21 is not useful for assessing ovulation, as LH levels peak around mid-cycle and are not elevated during the luteal phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, measuring serum progesterone on day 21 is the appropriate method to evaluate for ovulation, with levels above 10 ng/mL indicating that ovulation has occurred.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg435

questions.text: A district in Madhya Pradesh has CBR 19/1000 LB and CDR is 6/1000 LB. Find the annual growth rate of the district. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1.3%

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated using the formula:

 

Annual Growth Rate (AGR) = Crude Birth Rate (CBR) − Crude Death Rate (CDR)

 

In this case:

 

  • CBR = 19 per 1000 live births
  • CDR = 6 per 1000 live births

 

AGR = 19−6 = 13 per 1000

 

To express this as a percentage (which is the standard form for growth rates), you multiply by 0.1:

 

13 × 0.1 = 1.3%

 

Therefore, the annual growth rate for this district is 1.3%.

 

Additional Information –

 

  • Mid-year population is refer to the 1st of July.
  • India is in Stage 3 of Demographic cycle

 

Educational Objective:

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated by subtracting the Crude Death Rate (CDR) from the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) and then expressing this difference as a percentage.

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of Regression

 

Coefficient of Regression can be used to calculate one variable using another variable.

 

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

 

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Coefficient of Correlation:  Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

 

Option C.  The Coefficient of Variation: Is a measure of the relative variability of a dataset.

 

Option D. The Coefficient of Determination: Is a measure that determines the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

questions.text: A concerned mother reports that her adolescent daughter has developed unusual eating behaviors over the past few months. The daughter consumes multiple burgers in a single sitting and has observed her vomiting after the meals on multiple occasions. The daughter's BMI is calculated at 27. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The clinical presentation of binge eating (consuming multiple burgers in a single sitting) followed by purging (vomiting after meals) in a person with a higher BMI is indicative of bulimia nervosa. Bulimia nervosa is characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors such as vomiting, use of laxatives, or excessive exercise to prevent weight gain. Patients with bulimia nervosa usually have a normal or above-average BMI, distinguishing it from anorexia nervosa, where patients are typically underweight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa: While anorexia nervosa can involve binge eating and purging, it is usually associated with a significantly lower BMI. The patient would typically be underweight, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Pica: Pica involves the consumption of non-food items, such as soil or chalk, and does not involve binge eating or purging behaviors.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder: This disorder involves recurrent episodes of binge eating without subsequent purging or other compensatory behaviors. The absence of purging behavior in binge eating disorder differentiates it from bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:


Bulimia nervosa is characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by purging, often seen in individuals with a normal or above-average BMI.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed to have CFTR gene mutations. What is the defective channel? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cl

 

Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR) gene mutations lead to defective chloride channels. The CFTR protein regulates the transport of chloride ions across epithelial cell membranes. In cystic fibrosis, mutations in the CFTR gene result in dysfunctional chloride channels, leading to the production of thick, sticky mucus. This thick mucus can cause various problems, including chronic respiratory infections, pancreatic enzyme insufficiency, and other complications.

 

The defective chloride channels are the underlying cause of the clinical manifestations seen in cystic fibrosis, as they disrupt the normal movement of chloride and sodium ions in and out of cells, thereby affecting the hydration and viscosity of secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na:  Sodium channels are not primarily affected by CFTR mutations. Although sodium transport can be indirectly affected due to the dysfunction in chloride transport, sodium channels themselves are not defective in cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C. K: Potassium channels are not involved in the pathophysiology of cystic fibrosis. The disease specifically involves chloride transport.

 

Option D. Ca:  Calcium channels are not affected by CFTR gene mutations. The defective channel in cystic fibrosis is specific to chloride ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride channels, which are responsible for the thick, sticky mucus characteristic of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with joint pain and weakness. The patient is diagnosed as a case of Homocystinuria, and cysteine level is low. Which vitamin is required in the treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6


Homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder often caused by a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase, which requires Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) as a cofactor. This enzyme plays a crucial role in the metabolism of homocysteine to cysteine. When Vitamin B6 is deficient or the enzyme is non-functional, homocysteine accumulates, leading to elevated levels of homocysteine in the blood and a decrease in cysteine levels. The clinical presentation often includes symptoms such as joint pain, weakness, and an increased risk of thromboembolic events. Treatment with Vitamin B6 helps facilitate the conversion of homocysteine to cysteine, reducing homocysteine levels and correcting the associated symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Riboflavin plays a role in various metabolic processes but is not directly involved in the conversion of homocysteine to cysteine. It does not address the enzyme deficiency seen in Homocystinuria.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine is essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nervous system function but does not have a direct role in the metabolism of homocysteine or the treatment of Homocystinuria.

 

Option D. Vitamin B7 (Biotin): Biotin is involved in carboxylation reactions in fatty acid synthesis and gluconeogenesis, but it does not influence the homocysteine-cysteine pathway, making it irrelevant to the treatment of Homocystinuria.

 

Educational Objective:


Vitamin B6 is essential in the treatment of Homocystinuria as it acts as a cofactor for the enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase, helping convert homocysteine to cysteine and preventing its accumulation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is the bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – A feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray image shown in the question is diagnostic of Giant cell tumor of the distal end of radius.
  • Tumor of distal end radius is GCT, until proved otherwise.

questions.text: Twin pregnancy where 1 twin is older by 1 month than the other on ultrasound. What is this known as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfetation


Superfetation is the phenomenon where two ova are released in separate menstrual cycles and are fertilized at different times, leading to the conception of twins with different gestational ages. This means that one twin is conceived at a later date than the other, which can result in an observable difference in size or developmental stage on ultrasound. Although superfetation is documented in some animals, it is extremely rare and largely theoretical in humans due to the cessation of ovulation after the first conception. Nonetheless, it is the best explanation for the scenario where one twin appears to be older by a month than the other.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfecundation: Superfecundation occurs when two ova released in the same menstrual cycle are fertilized by separate acts of intercourse. The twins conceived have the same gestational age, although they may vary slightly in size. This phenomenon does not explain a one-month difference in age between twins.

 

Option C. Illegitimate: This term is not a medical explanation related to twin pregnancies. It refers to a non-scientific or socially defined concept and does not pertain to any biological condition involving twins.

 

Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic: This refers to twins that share both the chorion and the amniotic sac, resulting from the splitting of a single fertilized egg. These twins are identical and have the same gestational age; they do not account for any significant size or age discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:


Superfetation refers to a rare phenomenon where twins are conceived at different times, resulting in a significant difference in gestational ages, although it is mostly theoretical in humans.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of abdominal pain and fever for the past three days presents to the hospital. The physician orders a chest X-ray in the erect position which shows abnormal findings. Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis will be determined? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • Air under the diaphragm is seen in the given erect radiograph, which is a characteristic finding of hollow viscus perforation.
  •  Perforation of a viscus can lead to peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum due to the spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Clinical features of hollow viscus perforation include abdominal pain, distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, and guarding on palpation.
  •  Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric volvulus: Gastric volvulus refers to the twisting of the stomach on its axis. It can result in obstruction and ischemia. Symptoms include severe epigastric pain, vomiting, and difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube. On imaging, the stomach may be abnormally positioned, often with a characteristic appearance described as an "inverted stomach" or "upside-down stomach." While it can cause serious complications, air under the diaphragm on an erect chest radiograph is not typically associated with gastric volvulus.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is typically caused by bacterial or amoebic infection. Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss. An erect chest radiograph isn't the primary modality to diagnose a liver abscess. Instead, an ultrasound or CT scan of the abdomen would be more appropriate to visualize an abscess within the liver.

 

Option D. Empyema thoracis: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity (space between the lung and the chest wall). It's usually a complication of pneumonia or thoracic surgery. Symptoms include fever, cough, chest pain, and breathlessness. On a chest radiograph, the empyema may appear as a fluid level or a white opacity, depending on its stage and the amount of fluid. An erect chest X-ray may be used to diagnose empyema, but it would not typically show free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Air under the diaphragm seen on an erect chest radiograph is a hallmark finding of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate attention to prevent peritonitis and other severe complications.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

A-3. Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living amoeba uses pseudopodia for locomotion.

 

B-2. Balantidium coli, is a ciliated protozoan (and the largest protozoan that infects humans)

 

C-1. Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, flagellated protozoan parasite.

 

D-4.Toxoplasma gondii is a member of the phylum Apicomplexa, a diverse group of intracellular parasites that share a unique form of gliding motility. Gliding is substrate dependent and occurs without apparent changes in cell shape and in the absence of traditional locomotory organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balamuthia mandrillaris: Uses pseudopodia for movement.
  • Balantidium coli: Uses cilia for locomotion.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis: Uses flagella for movement.
  • Toxoplasma gondii: Exhibits gliding motility, a substrate-dependent movement without the use of traditional locomotory organelles.

questions.text:
What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Wide local excision
  2. Axillary node dissection
  3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery
  4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Wide local excision:

 

  • This involves the removal of the breast tumor and a margin of surrounding normal tissue. The goal is to ensure that no cancer cells remain at the site, while preserving as much of the breast's appearance and function as possible.

 

2. Axillary node dissection:

 

  • This procedure involves removing lymph nodes from the axilla to check for the spread of cancer. If the sentinel lymph node biopsy (a procedure to remove the first node(s) that breast cancer is likely to spread) shows cancer, more extensive lymph node surgery might be done.

 

3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery:

 

  • A frozen section involves rapidly freezing a tissue sample from the patient during surgery. A pathologist then examines the tissue under a microscope. This procedure allows for an immediate diagnosis, which can guide surgical decisions during the procedure, such as whether wider excision is needed if margins are not clear.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional:

 

  • This statement is incorrect in the context of Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS). Post-operative radiotherapy is essential after BCS to reduce the risk of local recurrence of the tumor in the preserved breast tissue. It is not optional; rather, it's a standard part of the treatment plan in most cases.

 

Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:

 

a. Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor

 

b. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative)

 

c. Post-operative radiotherapy – given in all cases of BCT

 

d. If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proptosis

 

The image shows a Hertel exophthalmometer, which is specifically designed to measure proptosis—the forward displacement of the eye. 

 

This instrument directly measures how much the eyeball protrudes forward from the eye socket. It is essential in diagnosing conditions like thyroid eye disease where proptosis is a common feature.

 

  • Design and Use: It consists of a ruler and two lateral mirrors or prisms that align with the lateral orbital rim, allowing for accurate measurement of the anterior position of the cornea relative to the lateral orbital wall.
    1. Bilateral Assessment: The Hertel exophthalmometer can measure the protrusion of both eyes simultaneously, allowing for comparison between the two. This is vital for identifying asymmetrical proptosis, which can be an indicator of more serious unilateral orbital disease.
    2. Quantitative Data: It provides quantitative data that can help in monitoring the progression or resolution of orbital diseases over time. This is particularly useful in tracking the effectiveness of treatment for conditions that cause proptosis.
    3. Simple and Non-invasive: The device is straightforward to use and non-invasive, making it a patient-friendly tool for regular follow-up assessments in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Infertility
  2. Dysmenorrhea
  3. Vaginal discharge
  4. Vaginal bleeding
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside the uterus. This condition is associated with specific symptoms:

 

1. Infertility: Women with endometriosis often experience difficulty conceiving. The presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus can interfere with the reproductive organs, leading to infertility.

 

2. Dysmenorrhea: Painful menstruation is a hallmark of endometriosis. This condition can cause severe menstrual cramps due to the endometrial tissue responding to hormonal changes as it would in a normal menstrual cycle.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 3, 4: Vaginal discharge and vaginal bleeding are not characteristic symptoms of endometriosis. Vaginal discharge may be seen in various other conditions but is not specific to endometriosis. Similarly, while endometriosis can cause abnormal bleeding, it typically presents with pain rather than increased vaginal bleeding.

 

Option B. 2, 3: While dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) is a symptom of endometriosis, vaginal discharge is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Dysmenorrhea is indeed a symptom of endometriosis, but increased vaginal bleeding is not a primary symptom of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis commonly presents with symptoms including dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and infertility.


Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: In which of the following will you NOT do induction of labor? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central Placenta Previa

 

Explanation:

 

Induction of labor involves starting labor artificially in a patient who is not already in labor, usually to expedite delivery due to various maternal or fetal indications such as fetal growth restriction, post-term pregnancy, oligohydramnios, or preeclampsia. The goal of induction is to achieve vaginal delivery.

 

However, induction is contraindicated in situations where vaginal delivery is not possible or safe, as in central placenta previa, where the placenta completely covers the cervical os. Attempting vaginal delivery in this situation can lead to severe hemorrhage as contractions begin. Therefore, a cesarean section is indicated for central placenta previa to avoid the risk of bleeding and ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligohydramnios: Induction is indicated to avoid complications from low amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Induction is recommended at 37 weeks for mild preeclampsia and at 34 weeks for severe preeclampsia to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

Option D. PROM: Induction is required if labor does not start spontaneously to prevent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Induction of labor is contraindicated in central placenta previa due to the risk of severe hemorrhage, necessitating a cesarean section for safe delivery.

questions.text: Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent congenitally in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic fibrosis

 

  • Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent, congenitally in cystic fibrosis. This is known as the congenital bilateral absence of vas deference (CBAVD) and is a causes of obstructive azoospermia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome (47 XXY) accounts or 1 to 2 percent of male infertility cases. Classically, these men are tall, undervirilized, and have gynecomastia and small, rm testes

 

Option C. Kallman syndrome: This is a form of congenital hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism with anosmia. It presents as primary amenorrhoea in women and with male infertility in men

 

Option D. Kartagener syndrome: Kartagener's syndrome is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder comprising the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is associated with congenital bilateral absence of the seminal vesicles and vas deferens, leading to obstructive azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 229, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts
Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts
Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

 

Explanation:

 

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This process takes place in two waves:
    • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
    • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.

 

Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 Weeks

 

Congenital biliary atresia is a condition where the bile ducts are blocked or absent, leading to bile accumulation in the liver. This condition often presents with jaundice that persists beyond the normal neonatal period.

 

This option is correct. If jaundice is present beyond the first 2 weeks of an infant's life, it is a significant indicator to suspect congenital biliary atresia. Early diagnosis is crucial for better outcomes, and any persistent jaundice beyond this period warrants further investigation for possible biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond 2 weeks.

questions.text: What is the observational unit in ecological investigations? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Population

 

  • In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population or community, which refers to a group of individuals or entities living in the same geographic area or sharing a common characteristic.
  • Ecological studies are observational studies that investigate the relationship between exposure and disease at a population level rather than an individual level.
  • Therefore, the data collected and analyzed in ecological studies are not at the individual level, but at the group or population level.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 cm per month

 

During the first three months of life, the head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month. This rapid growth is due to the significant brain development occurring during this period. After the first three months, the growth rate slows down. From three to six months of age, the head circumference increases by about 1 cm per month, and from six months to one year, it increases by about 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

choices.text: Blast of air

questions.text: A man who was involved in a bomb blast at a railway station was brought to the hospital with multiple small puncture wounds to the left side of the chest and multiple small abrasions all over the body. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for these injuries? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flying missiles

 

The case scenarios define multiple abrasions and puncture wounds suggestive of blast injuries due to flying missiles.

 

T.K. Marshall's (Marshall's triad of bomb injuries) :

 

    • Abrasions
    • Bruises/contusions
    • Puncture lacerations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blast of air: Primarily causes primary blast injuries, which affect air-filled organs and do not typically result in puncture wounds.

 

Option C. Explosion burns: Involve thermal injuries and burns rather than puncture wounds and abrasions.

 

Option D. Furniture abrasions: Would result from the victim being thrown into furniture or debris, causing blunt force injuries rather than puncture wounds.

 

Educational Objective

 

Classification of Blast injuries:

 

Injuries from explosions are traditionally classified into:

 

  1. Primary blast injuries: injuries due to solely to the blast wave
  2. Secondary blast or explosive injury: primarily ballistic trauma resulting from fragmentation wounds from the explosive device or the environment
  3. Tertiary blast or explosive injury: result of displacement of the victim or environmental structures, is largely blunt traumatic injuries
  4. Quaternary explosive injuries: burns, toxins, and radiologic contamination

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about behavior change stages and choose the correct answer :(INICET NOV 2023)

 

  • Statement 1: Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking.
  • Statement 2: Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walk considering its benefits to health.
  • Statement 3: Maintenance phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then.
  • Statement 4: Action phase – A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs in his family.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

The behavior change model, often based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM), outlines various stages individuals go through when changing a behavior as given below.

 

 

Statement 1: Correct. Contemplation involves thinking about quitting a behavior, such as smoking, which fits the scenario described.

 

Statement 3: Correct. The maintenance phase describes someone who has successfully sustained a behavior change, such as quitting smoking, over a long period.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Precontemplation is the stage where a person is not yet considering a change. In this case, considering starting a morning walk suggests the contemplation stage instead.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. This statement reflects a precontemplation attitude where the person is not considering change, attributed to a belief that obesity is inevitable due to family history, rather than being in the action phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct definitions of stages of behavior change is crucial in accurately assessing an individual's readiness to modify behaviors , based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM).

questions.text: What is the test of significance conducted for two or more proportions? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used to determine if there is a significant association between categorical variables. It is especially useful for testing the relationship between two or more proportions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Student's test: This typically refers to the t-test, which is used to compare means between two groups. It is not appropriate for proportions.

 

Option C. Z test: While the Z test can be used for proportions, it is usually employed for large sample sizes and comparing the means of two populations.

 

Option D. ANOVA: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups, not for comparing proportions.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

questions.text: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two different ova released in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse occurring within a short period of time. This can result in twins with different fathers if the sperm comes from two different men, a phenomenon known as heteropaternal superfecundation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse: This describes the fertilization of two ova by sperm from a single act of intercourse, which is not superfecundation but simply the result of one intercourse fertilizing two ova simultaneously.

 

Option C. Both of the above: While it includes the correct scenario of superfecundation, it also includes an incorrect scenario, making it partially correct.

 

Option D. None of the above: This indicates that none of the given scenarios are correct, which is inaccurate as option B is correct.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova released during the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse.

 

Ref: Page 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding primary and secondary immune response? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given statement that antibody affinity is higher in the primary immune response and lower in the secondary immune response is incorrect. The correct comparison should be:

 

  • Primary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of the first contact with an antigen. It typically involves a longer lag period (4-10 days) before antibodies are produced. The initial antibodies produced are primarily IgM, with lower affinity for the antigen.
  • Secondary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of subsequent exposures to the same antigen. It involves a shorter lag period (1-3 days) due to the presence of memory cells. The antibodies produced are primarily IgG, which have higher affinity for the antigen compared to those produced in the primary response. The secondary response is more rapid and robust, producing higher levels of antibodies that persist for a longer period.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Lag period: Correctly identified; the primary immune response has a longer lag period (4-10 days), while the secondary immune response has a shorter lag period (1-3 days).

 

Option B. Antibody response: Correctly identified; the secondary immune response is more potent than the primary immune response.

 

Option C. Isotype generated: Correctly identified; the primary response mainly produces IgM, while the secondary response mainly produces IgG.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: Which of these is a contraindication to the use of BiPAP ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unconscious patient

 

Explanation:

 

BiPAP, or Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure, is a non-invasive ventilation method that provides two levels of pressure: higher inspiratory positive airway pressure (IPAP) and lower expiratory positive airway pressure (EPAP). It is commonly used in various respiratory conditions but has contraindications. An unconscious patient may not be able to protect their airway, which increases the risk of aspiration. Such patients are typically not candidates for non-invasive ventilation like BiPAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OSA (Obstructive Sleep Apnea): BiPAP can be used as a treatment for OSA to prevent airway collapse during sleep.

 

Option C. High CO2 (Hypercapnia): BiPAP is often used for hypercapnic respiratory failure because it can help blow off excess CO2.

 

Option D. Low Oxygen (Hypoxemia): While BiPAP can help improve oxygenation by increasing the alveolar ventilation, it may not be sufficient in cases of severe hypoxemia where invasive ventilation might be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BiPAP is contraindicated in unconscious patients due to the increased risk of aspiration and inability to protect their airway.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin + heparin

 

Explanation

 

Aspirin + heparin:

 

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction.
  • The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes:
    • Low dose aspirin: Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta.
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin only: While low-dose aspirin is beneficial, it is not sufficient alone for the prevention of complications in APS. The addition of heparin provides better protection against thrombosis and pregnancy loss.

 

Option C. Aspirin + heparin + steroids: Steroids are not routinely used in the management of APS during pregnancy due to their potential side effects and lack of evidence showing added benefit in preventing pregnancy loss when combined with aspirin and heparin.

 

Option D. Aspirin + steroids: Similar to the previous option, steroids are not recommended as part of the standard management for APS in pregnancy. The combination of aspirin and heparin is the preferred treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2907, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Triage is categorization of victims of Disaster. Correct match for the categories of Triage is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yellow – Stable, Need observation

 

Explanation:

 

Triage is the process of sorting and categorizing victims based on the likelihood of survival and the urgency of their need for medical treatment.

Triage categorizes victims to prioritize treatment based on the urgency and likelihood of survival, with yellow indicating stable patients who need observation but can wait for treatment.

Yellow is the Minimal Category

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red – Least priority: This is incorrect as red indicates the highest priority, requiring immediate intervention (Emergency category).

 

Option B. Black – Minor injuries, Immediate priority: This is incorrect as black represents deceased or moribund patients, not those with minor injuries.

 

Option D. Green – Life threatening: This is incorrect as green indicates minor injuries that are not life-threatening and can wait for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a disaster, victims are categorized into four primary colors:

 

  • Red: This category includes patients who require immediate resuscitation or life/limb-saving surgery within 0-6 hours to prevent death.
  • Yellow: These patients may require resuscitation or life/limb-saving surgery, but their treatment can be delayed up to 6-24 hours without immediate risk to life.
  • Green: These patients have minor, non-life-threatening injuries such as small fractures, abrasions, bruises, or lacerations. They are ambulatory and can wait for medical care.
  • Black: This category includes deceased or moribund patients who are beyond the possibility of resuscitation.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of low-risk prostatic carcinoma. The most likely management for this patient would be active surveillance only.

  • Active surveillance is a management approach used for prostate cancer with specific criteria.
  • Criteria for active surveillance include Gleason score 6, early-stage disease (T1), small volume disease on biopsy, age > 70 years and low PSA (<10 ng/mL).
  • Active surveillance protocols include regular digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical prostatectomy: This surgical procedure involves removing the entire prostate gland. It is often considered for prostate cancer treatment, especially for younger, healthier patients or those with more aggressive forms of the disease.

 

Option B. External beam radiation: This treatment involves using targeted radiation beams to kill cancer cells. It can be considered for prostate cancer, particularly when surgery is not an option. The choice between radiation therapy and active surveillance depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the stage and aggressiveness of the cancer.

 

Option C. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy where radioactive seeds or sources are placed directly into or near the tumor. It's a localized treatment and can be used for low to intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Again, the decision to use brachytherapy depends on several factors, including the patient's overall health and the characteristics of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels.
  • This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.

questions.text:
Which of the provided options align with the depicted equivalence margin graph? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

 

  1. ‘A’ represents superiority of new treatment
  2. ‘I’ represents Inferiority of new treatment
  3. ‘E’ represents Non-inferior treatment
  4. ‘C’ is inconclusive
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2 and 3 

 

There are three types of comparators in Randomised Control Trials:

 

1. Superiority Trial – New drug is Better than old drug

 

2. Non-Inferiority Trial – New drug as good as old drug

 

3. Equivalence – New drug same as old drug

 

 

Other Option:

 

4. 'C' is inconclusive: This statement is incorrect as per the image. 'C' represents a superior treatment, as it falls well into the "new treatment better" region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In equivalence margin graphs for RCTs, 'A' can indicate a superior treatment, 'I' an inferior treatment, and 'E' a non-inferior treatment. 'C' does not represent an inconclusive result; it represents superiority.

questions.text: Efferent to which nucleus of thalamus from indicated structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

 

 

The image shows a coronal section of the brain with the indicated structure being the fornix. The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is involved in the Papez circuit, which plays a key role in the control of memory functions.

 

  • Anterior Nucleus of the Thalamus: The fornix carries signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is an integral part of the Papez circuit, involved in emotional and memory processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral: The lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in sensory relay and integration but are not the primary efferent targets of the fornix.

 

Option C. Ventro-postero-lateral: This nucleus is involved in the relay of sensory information from the body to the brain but is not connected to the fornix.

 

Option D. Pulvinar: The pulvinar nucleus is involved in visual processing and attention, not directly associated with the fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

questions.text: A patient had a drop in Systolic Blood Pressure of 15 mm Hg during inspiration. Which of the following is NOT associated with it? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation

 

A drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration is termed pulsus paradoxus. This phenomenon is seen in several conditions, including cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax.

 

Cardiac tamponade is a classic cause of pulsus paradoxus due to the restriction of ventricular filling during inspiration. Status asthmaticus and tension pneumothorax also cause significant intrathoracic pressure changes, leading to a similar hemodynamic effect.

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, on the other hand, is not associated with pulsus paradoxus. Instead, HCM can be associated with pulsus bisferiens, a double-peaked pulse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac Tamponade: This is a well-known cause of pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option B. Status Asthmaticus: This can cause pulsus paradoxus due to severe obstruction and changes in intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Tension Pneumothorax: This condition can also lead to pulsus paradoxus due to significant intrathoracic pressure changes.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulsus paradoxus, a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, is seen in conditions like cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax. It is not associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can present with pulsus bisferiens instead.

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.

 

Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.

 

Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.

 

Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin

 

Ciprofloxacin is commonly used for mass chemoprophylaxis in cases of meningococcal meningitis, particularly among close contacts of an infected individual. It is effective in preventing the spread of Neisseria meningitidis, the bacterium responsible for meningococcal disease. Ciprofloxacin is preferred due to its broad-spectrum activity, ease of administration as a single-dose regimen, and good penetration into the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: While used for treatment of meningococcal meningitis, it is not used for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Not used in the prophylaxis or treatment of meningococcal meningitis.

 

Option D. Penicillin: Although used for treatment, penicillin is not typically used for prophylaxis against meningococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciprofloxacin, Rifampicin, Ceftriaxone is indicated in the chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts to prevent secondary cases.

 

Ceftriaxone is preferred in children < 18 years and pregnancy.
